briefOverview: A revelation emphasizing forgiveness, church discipline, and stewardship while reaffirming Joseph Smith’s authority and outlining instructions for building Zion. It urges sacrifice and tithing now, with promises and warnings regarding Zion’s future and divine judgment.
summary: The Lord addresses the elders, calling them to overcome the world, extending compassion, and pronouncing forgiveness “for this once,” while affirming that the keys of the kingdom remain with Joseph Smith if he obeys. He reproves those who have unjustly sought occasion against Joseph and teaches that disciples must forgive all people, leaving final judgment to God, while unrepentant offenders are to be brought before the church. Specific rebukes and mercies are given to Ezra Booth, Isaac Morley, and Edward Partridge, with instructions for Sidney Gilbert to return to his agency in Zion and for certain property decisions to avoid temptation and to maintain a stronghold in Kirtland for five years. The Lord requires sincere hearts, declares this a day of sacrifice and tithing, warns of coming burning upon the proud and the wicked, and counsels labor “today.” He directs Newel K. Whitney and Sidney Gilbert not to sell current holdings yet, reminds them that acting as agents in God’s will is the Lord’s business, and assures the saints will obtain an inheritance in Zion in due time. The saints are urged not to weary in well-doing, as small things lead to great, and the willing and obedient will enjoy Zion’s blessings, while the rebellious will be cut off. The church is likened to a judge on a hill, charged to judge matters pertaining to Zion, exposing liars and hypocrites, and ensuring unfaithful leaders are replaced, with promises that Zion will flourish and become an ensign to all nations.
externalContext: This revelation was given in Kirtland, Ohio, in September 1831, shortly after some leaders had traveled to Jackson County, Missouri, which had been designated as “Zion.” Figures named here—Newel K. Whitney (a Kirtland bishop and store owner), Sidney Gilbert (appointed as an agent in Missouri), Edward Partridge (bishop in Zion), Isaac Morley, Frederick G. Williams, and Ezra Booth—were key early leaders facing logistical, spiritual, and interpersonal strains as the Church expanded. Ezra Booth had become a vocal critic after disillusionment from the Missouri journey, contributing to public controversy. The instruction about Kirtland as a “strong hold” for five years aligns with the period leading up to the Kirtland Temple era (mid‑1830s), while the counsel on tithing reflects early development of consecration and financial support before later formalization of tithing practice.
externalReferences: The mandate to forgive all people parallels Jesus’ teaching that God forgives those who forgive others (Matthew 6:14–15) and the warning of the unmerciful servant (Matthew 18:21–35). The assurance of priesthood “keys” entrusted to Joseph Smith resonates with the promise of keys to Peter (Matthew 16:19). Imagery of coming judgment and the wicked as “stubble” echoes Malachi 4:1. Promises to the “willing and obedient” reflect Isaiah 1:19, and Zion as an “ensign” for the nations draws on Isaiah’s ensign motif (e.g., Isaiah 11:12).
practicalQuestions: Whom do I still need to forgive, and how can I leave ultimate judgment to God while seeking appropriate accountability?
How should I contribute time and resources “today” to advance God’s work without becoming weary?
What stewardship or property decisions in my life should be guided by faith, counsel, and timing rather than impulse?
How can I cultivate a willing heart and mind so that obedience becomes my natural response?
In community leadership or membership, how do we balance compassion with clear standards when someone refuses to repent?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning of “sinned unto death” is not specified; the statement about a five‑year “strong hold” in Kirtland may be temporal or conditional; “blood of Ephraim” is not defined; the scope and measure of “tithing” here are not quantified; and the timeline metaphor of “today/tomorrow” in the burning imagery leaves the timing of judgment unspecified.
